item.title: This is Our Muon Shot
item.description: In December, the Particle Physics Project Prioritization Panel, called P5, released its recommendations for the future of the field, based on the input from the Snowmass process.

item.title: The Dream Machine
item.description: A muon collider could be much smaller and cheaper than a functionally equivalent proton collider, advocates say.

item.title: Particle Physicists Offer a Road Map for the Next Decade
item.description: A “muon shot” aims to study the basic forces of the cosmos.

item.title: Particle Physicists Dream of a Muon Collider
item.description: Particle physicists are unlikely evangelists, but in papers, at conferences and with T-shirts, stickers and memes, many of them are spreading the good word of a muon collider—a next-generation machine that would smash together muons, the massive cousins of electrons.

item.title: Particle physicists want to build the world’s first muon collider
item.description: Momentum is growing to build a particle collider in the United States that smashes muons — heavier cousins of electrons.

item.title: Muon Colliders Hold a Key to Unraveling New Physics
item.description: As the discovery of the Higgs boson approaches its 10-year anniversary, physicists are busy building on its legacy.

item.title: MICE brings muon collider closer to reality
item.description: Scientists have announced a breakthrough that could be key to the creation of a powerful new kind of particle collider.
